32.86.text:
Coming up. It is a kind of fox shooting, but
not as we know it. We are in Africa where

38.21.text: it is the night and the day of the jackal.

41.33.text:
Mark Gilchrist has taken his gun to Ireland,
where the crows are piling in.

46.07.text:
First, it is the start of National Shooting
Week and to promote it, the Countryside Alliance

53.49.text:
has taken a load of urban kids to a clay ground
in Kent.

58.33.text:
A school trip to Kent usually means Chatham
Dockyard or Leeds Castle, but for these inner

63.73.text:
city London children, it is West Kent Shooting
School.

67.47.text:
They are here as part of the Countryside Alliance's
National Shooting Week, to learn all about

72.31.text:
a sport which requires skill, coordination
and discipline. All qualities which should

77.36.text:
be impressed upon children of any age. Oh
yes, they are going to learn it is from, to.......

82.99.text:
It is an exciting experience for them to try
the sport. It is an Olympic sport now, shooting.

87.75.text:
It is a good opportunity to get them into
something they have not done before. None

89.66.text:
of the children here today have done shooting
before. They are really looking forward to

95.93.text: How do you sell it to their parents?

98.72.text:
Good question. It is just an opportunity for
them to do a different sport they have not

103.05.text:
done before. Parents were willing for them
to come, they thought it was a good idea.

108.56.text:
The Durand Academy is not one of those schools
you hear about on the news. It is a good place

113.18.text:
to learn. Ofsted class it as outstanding,
but their knowledge of what they are doing

118.84.text:
... said it was going to be laser tag and
I thought no....I thought it was not going

128.56.text:
First of all it is the intro. Some safety
briefing followed by a quick explanation of

134.04.text:
what makes the cartridge go bang. Then a willing
volunteer puts a shell through the gun to

143.01.text: What a shot. You hit it.

145.81.text:
It is the first of hundreds that will be fired
today. Bringing many smiles to many faces.

156.22.text:
When they first came here they were a bit
quiet. I think they were a little bit nervous.

160.48.text:
As soon as they set fire to some powder there
they got very excited and saw a big flame

166.62.text:
there. You could see they all got interested
at that point. Then they got to shoot a pattern

169.91.text:
plate, they were all very excited then, they
heard the first bang. But now they have all

173.28.text:
had to have a go, they are all engrossed.
They are all trying to beat eachother. They

177.35.text:
are all competitive. They are all enjoying
it. Smiles everywhere.

179.95.text:
There is no doubt the 10 year olds are having
a ball. But they are from London and have

184.08.text:
never been exposed to anything like this in
their lives before. So what do they make of

188.64.text:
it. And most importantly, would they do it
again.

191.20.text: What has been the best bit?

196.54.text: It is cool, it is really good.

200.76.text:
It goes back on your shoulder. But it does
not hurt as much as you think it would.

207.23.text:
And what does it feel like to actually hit
one?

208.42.text:
I never knew it was going to be real guns.
I thought it would be like pellet guns.

213.25.text:
If you are going to tell your friends or your
family about the day, how are you going to

221.15.text: Would you come back and do this again?

224.14.text:
Lean forward, that is it, now put your head
down on the wood.

227.16.text:
West Kent has put on a great day. The instructors
here have been patient and enthusiastic and

232.22.text:
that has transferred to the children. All
of them have experienced the satisfaction

237.02.text:
of seeing that clay going pop. And some have
shown some natural flare.

242.22.text:
The Countryside Alliance is not expecting
to find the next shooting superstar today.

247.02.text:
It just wants to make sure that these children
come away positive thoughts about our sport.

253.85.text:
National Shooting Week is from the 2nd to
the 10th June 2012. To take part in an event

259.46.text:
over this half term, simply visit www.nationalshootingweek.co.uk
Find your nearest ground via a postcode search

277.27.text:
Now from one bunch of enthusiastic amateurs
to another. It is David on the Fieldsports

291.84.text:
An information panel on Birmingham's gun quarter
has been unveiled by Birmingham City Council

298.10.text:
next to the Gunmakers Arms on Little Shadwell
Street.

301.97.text:
This follows a worldwide campaign to save
the name of the gun quarter. Sadly, Tony Treadwell,

306.45.text:
who led the campaign, passed away from cancer
aged 45 on Easter Saturday. The campaign will

312.67.text:
be continued by representatives of the Birmingham
gun trade with the support of BASC.

319.06.text:
George Digweed has claimed yet another international
title. He won the European Compaq in a dramatic

325.48.text:
sudden death shoot off against local hero
Andras Szerdahelyi in Budapest. George and

331.88.text:
Andras both finished the tournament scoring
198 out of 200. George kept his cool in the

337.32.text:
shoot off to secure his 15th European title.
He told Fieldsports Channel News it was even

343.07.text:
more satisfying knowing he had shown 007 just
who was boss.

348.23.text:
The Lord of the Manor of Preston Patrick of
Westmorland has reasserted his 200-year-old

354.18.text:
right to hunt throughout the village in a
letter to local residents.

359.15.text:
Henry Armitage owns "Deeds of Enfranchisement"
dating back to 1773, but a law passed by the

364.74.text:
Labour government in 2002 voids any of these
traditional rights unless they are claimed

369.59.text:
by October 2013. The Daily Mail newspaper
found just one angry resident who opposes

377.12.text:
A shooter from New Zealand has shot the country's
oldest duck. While kayaking on the Kaituna

384.15.text:
River, Brian Rogers bagged a bird with a ring
on it dating back from 2002. The local Fish

389.37.text:
& Game department says it is pleased to see
shooters like Brian getting the most from

396.38.text:
And finally a Dutch artist has taken taxidermy
to a new level. After his cat, Orville, was

402.93.text:
killed by a car, Bart Jansen from the Netherlands
stuffed it and turned it into a helicopter

408.81.text:
as part of an art exhibition in Amsterdam.
Bart says "Now he is finally flying with the

415.00.text:
birds. The greatest goal a cat could ever
reach!" And for all the horrified antis, he

419.80.text:
adds: "For the cat lovers: it is tanned hide,
just like your shoes."

425.49.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

436.15.text:
Thank you David. One of the great preditors
of news there. And talking of preditors it

441.66.text:
has always struck us how similar fox shooting
in the UK is to coyotei hunting in America,

448.04.text: is to our next subject, Jackal in Africa.

457.62.text:
No, we have not discovered the elephants'
graveyard. It is the edge of the charmingly-named

465.43.text:
"death pit": a hole in the ground where all
the surplus bits of carcase unused as either

469.94.text:
food or trophy by the Blaser Safari Lodge
end up. We are hoping that this is the table

476.27.text: where the jackals will dine tonight...

478.43.text: So is this where you bring your victims?

479.87.text:
Yes, so this is all the leftovers we bring
them here.

484.74.text:
So everything you do not use from the antelope,
you bring them here. So you just leave them

491.36.text: No we have got a hole, a big hole back there.

494.63.text:
What happens is the hyenas and the vultures
and jackals, they go inside and they take

501.90.text:
it and pull it to where ever they want to
eat it, mostly up here and under that tree

505.24.text:
over there. That has also got some bones underneath
it.

510.21.text:
Right. Jackal control for you is like fox
control for us.

513.80.text: So shall we go and do some then?

518.94.text:
Just like at home, the Fox Pro is a popular
choice here in Africa, but clearly we are

524.72.text:
scrolling through a different menu. Karel
starts off with a jackal call, but I have

529.97.text:
a feeling we have arrived here a little late
for any action. I am not getting the same

534.59.text:
sort of foxing confidence that I get with
Roy back home.

539.02.text:
So we call it a night and deploy plan B the
following evening. There are plenty of takers,

545.21.text:
even though we are weary from a full day's
hunting. Somehow the idea of going foxing,

550.54.text:
or jackalling, appeals to the nostalgic side
of Germany-based Blaser Brit Darren Hull,

556.63.text:
and Zeiss's Stefan Buehring just wants to
be out hunting.

560.70.text:
Just like with the leopard in the laundry
we showed you a couple of weeks ago, Marc

564.70.text:
is taking us to see something slightly out
of the ordinary.

567.85.text:
We are heading off to the bottom section of
the property, where my maintenance manager

574.52.text:
found a dead giraffe. We are just going to
have a look at it to see if there are any

579.26.text:
jackal activity around it. If there is we
might just sit down there for may be an hour

586.85.text:
or two and maybe we will have a bit of luck
with a jackal.

592.13.text: Do you have any idea how the giraffe died.

593.72.text:
No, unfortunately not. We can not see any
marks on it. Obviously we did not find it

598.35.text:
quick enough. Part of it was chewed on already.
So it is difficult to say.

604.48.text:
Is it bad news when you lose an animal like
that?

608.19.text:
It is terrible news cause as I only released
that giraffe last August and they are all

615.26.text:
young animals. Probably 3 or 4 years old so
they are very young. It is a pity we have

621.65.text:
lost one and it looks like it is a bull so
that is always a pity.

626.88.text:
The giraffe blocks the whole track. If only
this was smellevision! The pictures in this

633.31.text: case only tell part of the story.

636.95.text:
Definitely looks like a young female, because
you can see the tuft of hair on top of the

643.16.text:
horn, which the females have. The bulls have
a bald patch on top and that is how you see

650.14.text:
the difference just by looking at the heads.
This is a youngster this is two or three years

655.78.text: What do you think killed it?

657.45.text:
I am not sure to be quite honest. I really
do not know. It is too late to see if there

666.48.text:
any marks on its neck, on its backside, on
its rump. A leopard would not really jump

674.28.text:
on to a giraffe it is just too big. But anything
is possible.

680.68.text:
If you look it looks like she fell down and
she was kicking. You can see the grass is

685.15.text:
flat where you are standing Darren. Looks
like she was doing this with her feet.

692.23.text: How long would you say she has been here?

700.51.text:
Probably about 3 or 4 days. She could have
been kicked in the stomach by another giraffe

709.68.text:
and all of a sudden she gets internal bleeding.
You know it so difficult to say. She could,

717.62.text:
I have been thinking now, she could have been
pregnant and she could have had a miscarriage

723.42.text:
or something went wrong. You know, it is so
difficult to say.

729.24.text:
Unfortunately the carcase doesn't have any
signs of scavengers, which makes Marc think

733.18.text:
twice about staying here. One possible theory
is that the animals are too wary, with the

740.86.text:
We found a dead zebra. When we hung the zebra
in the tree for a hyena we had to cut the

747.41.text:
head off because the hyenas otherwise would
not eat the meat, because they know that the

752.43.text:
zebras can bite them. If the head was off
then the hyenas ate it. I do not know if this

761.77.text:
is the case that the jackals think it is just
lying here because the head is still on. I

769.13.text:
We head off to glamorous destination number
2 - the death pit again... You can tell we

775.08.text:
are getting close. The vultures and marabou
storks give a sense that there is stuff round

779.65.text: here that is past its sell-by date.

783.10.text:
This time we get a better look at the death
pit. The smell does take some getting used

787.81.text:
to. Stuff rots in Africa a bit faster than
it does in the UK.

793.31.text:
Stefan is the man with the Blaser rifle tonight,
topped off with a perfect foxing/jackaling/coyoteing

799.59.text: or evn dingoing scope, the Zeiss Duralyt.

803.72.text:
Marc sets the FoxPro again - and we make ourselves
comfortable behind the death pit. We try and

809.00.text:
breathe through our mouths as the whiff on
the wind keeps us on our toes - but only for

813.78.text:
so long. As we lose the light Darren and Marc
try and get a different type of wind blowing

819.15.text:
when they change the call to lion, but their
tittering gives them away. No jackal. Next

825.84.text:
time Roy is coming with us to show Namibia
a few foxy tricks.

831.79.text:
Well if you enjoyed that piece about jackal
why not go and see our friends at the Shooting

835.31.text:
Show appearing in the little bit of sky beside
me there. They are after oryx this week. Staying

841.36.text:
with our show we are going to Ireland with
Mark Gilchrist, where the corvids are coming

846.12.text:
in thick and fast. Or should that be tick
and quick.

850.23.text:
Right, this week on Fieldsports Britain I
have gone over to Ireland to have a bit of

854.35.text:
crow shooting and stay with us for a bit longer,
because as you can see, we have got a fairly

859.11.text: decent day lined up for you.

909.31.text:
Now I have had a fantastic day over here in
the Republic of Ireland. The location has

935.40.text:
got to be kept a secret. That is part of the
deal that was struck up before I came over.

939.94.text:
We picked up about 150 jackdaws, we got 17
rooks and we have got the grey crows here

945.85.text:
which are the equivalent to the carrion crow
back in England, but obviously she is grey.

949.68.text:
We have got another 30 on the roof which we
can't get because the roof is too fragile

953.93.text:
to support my dainty weight. So we have got
to leave them up there. So that is a good

956.92.text:
job done, 500 shells, 2 hours. Now we are
going to see if the Guinness is good in the

962.19.text:
After a long, hard day's shooting there is
nothing I like more than a few pints, some

967.42.text:
local food and dive into a local pub. So when
I was given the chance to help with the Gaugers

972.23.text: Fish Nite I absolutely jumped at the opportunity.

975.41.text:
The Gaugers is a true sportsman establishment
offering guns and their dogs a place to dry

980.67.text:
off and eat one of their now famous breakfasts.
The half choke or the full choke.

985.79.text:
The business was set up under a year ago to
give wildfowlers, shooting people, gundog

991.59.text:
men, fishermen somewhere to come to, somewhere
comfortable to come to so that they can sit

995.93.text:
back, relax, bring their dog in, have a pint,
have some crack.

998.82.text:
Ok so what have you got that brings the people
in?

1002.74.text:
Breakfasts usually which give you the option
of a half choke which is a small fry, or a

1006.62.text: full choke which is a fry for a man.

1008.32.text: Right, so what is in a fry for a man?

1010.38.text:
Fry for a man, a full choke, you have got
2 beef sausages, 2 pork sausages, 2 bits of

1014.70.text:
bacon, 2 bits of vegetable roll, 2 bits of
soda bread, 2 bits of ... bread and 2 fried

1020.35.text:
And for those of you who don't know what vegetable
roll is? What is it?

1026.51.text:
Vegetable roll is somewhere along the lines
of sausage meat with onion, herbs, spices

1029.35.text:
in it. It is kind of like a small burger made
of pork.

1033.07.text: So there are not a lot of vegetables in it.

1035.20.text:
There are kind of very few vegetables in it.
The vegetables kind of walk past.

1038.88.text:
The fish nite is a real hit. After a few pints
of Guinness I throw in a few dishes of my

1043.70.text:
own. If you look around the punters are really
happy.

1047.77.text:
The pike was something I had never, ever tried
before and I thought it would be bony and

1049.52.text:
taste muddy, but it was really well seasoned
and really, really tasty.

1053.12.text:
I had the cured trout and it was really, really
nice. I had never had it before and it was

1061.48.text: delicious and I want more, it was really yummy.

1065.66.text:
I always have a fantastic time in Ireland
whether it is the sport, the food or the crack.

1072.98.text: The whole thing is pure genius.

1076.81.text:
Now Father's Day is coming up. Time to get
your wife, partner, girlfriend, civil partner,

1082.02.text:
boyfriend into the room with you, because
we have got a range of DVD's you can buy from

1087.02.text:
big game, to small game from fowl that fly
and fish that swim. It is all there on our

1093.22.text:
Now a round up of what is on YouTube in the
world of hunting, fishing, shooting this week.

1101.25.text:
It is Hunting YouTube, showing the best hunting,
shooting and fishing videos that YouTube has

1106.57.text:
to offer - and it is a bumper week for pest
control. Thanks to everyone who has sent in

1112.96.text:
ShootMorePigeons has put up a film called
'Lamping night rabbit shooting with a .22'.

1117.16.text:
It wins the award for title that most accurately
describes what is going on in the film, but

1121.62.text:
you are left a bit bereft in the plot department.
Like bad guys in a Bond movie, the rabbits

1126.61.text:
get shot but, unlike with 007, you do not
get any sense of who, what, where or why.

1132.25.text:
In the film 'Jackdaw Shooting' TweedsandPheasants
is shooting Jackdaws over decoys on a grass

1137.53.text:
field next to a cattle shed. Again, it is
a bit thin on story. Actually, I just told

1142.61.text: you the story. But you cannot fault the shooting.

1145.53.text:
'Stone the crows, it is Mark Gilchrist!' That
is the title of JamesMarchington's latest

1149.93.text:
film and it's the best film of the week. Mark
is up at 4am to protect a Kent farmer's barley

1155.61.text:
from marauding corvids. You find out why,
how and the only question you are left with

1160.61.text:
is who is the nice young lady who is happy
to go shooting with Mark at that time in the

1166.56.text:
HuntingFPS is one of the most popular British
shooting channels. In 'Slow Motion Airgun

1171.91.text:
Pigeon Hunting #16', his mission is pigeon
pie - and it does exactly what it says on

1177.99.text:
the tin. It is all in slow motion and shows
this channel's usual wit and style. You can

1183.19.text: see why viewers are so keen to watch his films.

1186.20.text:
For more unusual pigeon shooting, we join
Sportsman Channel's representative on earth

1190.82.text:
- or YouTube as we now call our planet - that
is WorldHuntingGroup. Its Argentina Pigeon

1196.29.text:
Schlock shows slow-motion mid-air shots at
pigeons with - be amazed - a bow and arrow

1202.12.text:
- be very amazed. It's a trailer for a film
on the US TV network Sportsman Channel but

1209.40.text:
Well, that was all the stuff that is good
for you. Now the fun stuff. Leo Naylor is

1213.88.text:
one of those British roebuck agents with such
good shooting they do not bother selling it

1217.85.text:
to ungrateful Brits. So it is that Dirk Waltmann
of the German hunting magazine Pirsch is out

1223.57.text:
with him on his ground in Somerset. Watch
this film - OK it is partly in German and

1228.70.text:
is a bit heavy on the still shots but give
it time - and it has better music than our

1233.83.text:
To Yorkshire, where UK01Edmund has put up
a film of the latest local inter pub shoot.

1239.52.text:
It is week 5. Goodness knows if you had sat
through weeks one to four of the first minute

1244.10.text:
of this you would think about turning the
gun on yourself but then it gets better with

1247.67.text: some proper Northern banter, so hold out.

1251.15.text:
And finally, it is an old one but a good one
for anyone who wants a cautionary tale about

1255.38.text:
muzzle awareness. In your opinion, does this
man deserve to be lucky? Doesn't a small part

1260.05.text:
of you wonder whether or not Darwin should
have been proven right here and the bloke

1263.81.text:
remove himself from our collective gene pool?
But he gets away with it.

1268.07.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1272.83.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1282.90.text:
We are back next week and once again you can
click on the speech button which is appearing

1287.73.text:
just beside me, exhorting you to subscribe
or even on the subscribe button which I think

1292.67.text:
is now permanently up there at the top of
the screen on YouTube. Or you can go to our

1296.83.text:
website where you can click to like us on
Facebook, or follow us on Twitter, or scroll

1301.69.text:
down to the bottom where there is a constant
contact box. Pop your email address into that

1306.15.text:
and we will send you our free weekly newsletter
about what is on the show. Good for us.

1311.55.text:
This has been Fieldsports Britain. Do not
forget about those DVD's.
